newsitem.title: UK: Britain's Hague wants referendum on new EU treaty.
newsitem.headline: Britain's Hague wants referendum on new EU treaty.

text.p: Britain's new Conservative leader William Hague called on Friday for a referendum on the EU treaty agreed by Labour Prime Minister Tony Blair at last week's Amsterdam summit.
"It's a question of sovereignty," a Hague aide told Reuters.

"Blair came back empty-handed," he said. "Imposing the EU Social Chapter will be disastrous for Britain. Fishermen gained nothing and the concessions on retaining border controls had already been won by Conservatives."

Blair said after the summit that he had done a deal to protect Britain's fishing industry from foreign fishermen buying up British quotas and that he had guaranteed Britain's border controls in a way which the Conservatives had failed to do.
He also reversed Conservative policy by signing up to the EU's Social Chapter, which guarantees employees certain minimum rights.
The referendum call was agreed unanimously at a shadow cabinet meeting on Wednesday, the aide said.
He denied that the call signalled a hardening of Hague's line on Europe, pointing out that Denmark is to hold a referendum on Amsterdam and France had held one on the Maastricht treaty.

Hague's call came in a speech to the annual Scottish Conservative conference, his first public appeal to rank-and-file members of a Scottish party stunned by a general election wipeout and riven by internal dissent.

He reiterated opposition to Labour plans for a separate Scottish parliament. The conference decided by a huge majority to campaign for a "No" vote in a referendum on a Scottish parliament but to work for maximum representation if a parliament is set up.
Opposition to any change in the 300-year-old link with England was a major factor in the party's disastrous election campaign.
